subject: Re: [junit] Re: one time setUp and tearDown
msgSnippet: ... OK. Let me see whether I understand. You have already tested your logic using a mock or in-memory file system *or* you have verified that your logic
messageBody:
>So said jbase@... on 2003-05-31 --------------------
>
>Just to clarify: the tool I was creating checks files/directories. I know
>the file system works, but does the application have the correct logic to
>walk the directories and select the right files. Some of the unit tests
>were robustness tests, driving the need for a number of different files
>(still checking program logic).

OK. Let me see whether I understand.

You have already tested your logic using a mock or in-memory file system *or* you have verified that your logic chooses the correct file system locations without worrying about whether you integrate correctly with the file system.

Now you want to be sure that you actually work with the file system, because there are I/O and interprocess issues that could break your application even in the presence of defect-free logic. Usually these are timing issues where the Java code executes too quickly and changes on the file system lag behind.

Is that the situation?

>I needed to create a known set of files and directories to test one of the
>methods. There were a number of tests. I agree, there is no technical
>reason to not create/destory the file/directories each time, other than I
>sometimes work on an older computer that is slow. The time to
>create/destory an interesting set of directories and files takes time on
>the slow machine and I like to run the tests after each change to the
>code. (I have gotten used to a fast desktop machine which may be driving
>my behavior...)

I agree. This is why I write as few tests as possible that use the real file system. I limit them to Customer Tests which have to work end-to-end, anyhow, in order to be useful. For Programmer Tests, though, I avoid the file system altogether except to verify that I remember how to use the file system.

>Could some of the test cases be integration tests, of course. This is a
>small home project with one developer and I have used Junit to test both
>methods and the application since Junit solves all my testing needs for
>this application.

Absolutely.

OK. I was just checking. My goal is to help people make maximal progress without worrying about these kinds of issues. It looks like you've already handled that.

I still don't understand the sense in which JUnit doesn't support one-time setup, though. It clearly does.

Take care.
